Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Conductive Polymer Wires and Cables for Energy Efficiency
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is that it presents a low cost, high quality, alternative to copper for electric power transmission and distribution. This project's new generation conductive polymer wire is durable, strong, light, and easy to manufacture cost-effectively. The new wire is seen as a potential replacement for copper, which is heavy and a commodity subject to significant price instabilities. This new technology could be disruptive in electric power industry. Lighter electronic devices will also be possible through this technology that could impact everything from portable devices to a reduction of the weight of automobiles and aircrafts. It also has the potential to revolutionize the current conductive polymer market.

This I-Corps project proposes a technology that may replace copper in electric power distribution and transmission. The proposed technology is based on a newly discovered carbon-based polymer with excellent electrical conductivity comparable to that of copper. This new material is durable, light, strong, and highly conductive with a high melting point over 1000C. Electric wires and cables can be easily manufactured cost effectively using the powder-in-tube technique with a copper sheath. Feasibility assessment requires exploration into fabrication of flexible wires for easy installation and handling and for good connectivity with copper wires, as well as exploring the potential customer base for this technology.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The outcomes of this NSF I-Corps project, no. 1646826, Conductive Polymer Wires and Cables for Energy Efficiency, are the following;

1. Intellectual Merit

During the project, we did research and development (R&D) of the new type of conductive polymeric material for electric power transmission and distribution. The polymeric material can be shiny, depending on the concentrations of ingredients, as shown in Figure 1. The pulverized powders are lightweight and float on the water, as shown in Figure 2., The electrical conductivity of this new polymeric material can easily reach about 30% of copper, with much higher strength, lightweight, and lower manufacturing cost. Note that steel, with electrical conductivity, 5%-15% of Copper, is used for 40% IACS (International Annealed Copper Standard) conductivity Copper clad steel wire for power delivery, https://fiskalloy.com/product/copper-clad-steel-40/.

We are trying to increase the conductivity over 50%, by identifying its molecular structre and conducting mechanism. Once we reach the milestone of over 50% conductiveity, our Cu-sheathed polymer wire technology can be disruptive in the power transmission and distribituon. We are almost ready to publish a paper on the molecular structure and the conducting mechanism of the new type of conductive polymeric material, based on TEM images and XRD data. We have also developed a reliable technology to manufacture Cu-sheathed conductive polymeric wire and cable for electric power transmission and distribution. The produced technology, as shown in Figure 3, has been submitted to the US PTO for a provisional patent, no. 62/812,033, and its information will be included in the iEdision procedure. The prototype Cu-sheated polymeric wire is shown in Figure 4.

2. Broader Impacts

This new Cu-sheathed polymeric wire and cable can penetrate the electric power industry market, first for applications where high strength and medium conductivity are required. It is also suited for high frequency signal applications. Once the conductivity of our new conductive polymeric material is reached over 50% of Copper, the resulting Cu-sheathed polymeric wire and cable can be used for most power transmission and distribution, because it has about 40% lower price, 30% light-weight, and 20% higher strength than Copper. This new polymeric material can be also used for manufacturing conductive filament for 3D printing. Figure 5 shows the conductive filament made by the conductive polymer and PLA, whereas Figure 6 shows the simple LED circuit, made by the conductive polymer 3d printing filament.

3. New startup, Cutting Edge Polymer, LLC, establsihed.

In June 8, 2017, Cutting Edge Polymer, LLC, was establsihed in Puerto Rico for commercializing this new polymeric wire and cable for electric power transmsission and distribution, https://www.cuttingedgepolymer.com/. We have sucessfully developed solid business networks with potential business partners, potential investors, and National labs and Universities in the USA. Cutting Edge Polymer, LLC can create many high-tech jobs for Puerto Ricans in this difficult economic situation.


Last Modified: 02/28/2019
Modified by: Yong-Jihn Kim

Addendum # 1

Recent TEM (Transmission Electron Microscopy) images show the nanostructures, such as nanotubes and nanoclusters, inside our shiny conductive polymer. The images are attached. If we grow the nanotubes and nanoclusters over a micron, our conductive polymer will show excellent electrical conductivity, almost the same as copper and will be very strong like steel. Accordingly, our conductive polymer wire and cable have great potential to replace copper wire and cable for electric power transmission and distribution. 


Added: 05/27/2019
Submitted by: Yong-Jihn Kim
